instruction: Respond to a citizen's question about trash collection
context: The user is asking when their trash will be collected during a holiday week.
response: During holiday weeks, trash collection is typically delayed by one day following the holiday. For example, if the holiday falls on a Monday, Monday's route will be collected on Tuesday, Tuesday's route on Wednesday, and so on through the week. You can also check the specific holiday collection schedule on our city website or by calling 311 directly.

instruction: Provide information about pothole reporting
context: The user has spotted a large pothole on their street and wants to know how to report it.
response: Thank you for helping keep our streets safe! You can report a pothole in several ways: 1) Through our city's mobile app, 2) On our website at [city].gov/potholes, 3) By calling 311 directly, or 4) By texting 'POTHOLE' to our service number. Please include the location (street address or intersection), the approximate size of the pothole, and a photo if possible. Our Public Works department typically addresses hazardous potholes within 48-72 hours.

instruction: Explain the process for obtaining a parking permit
context: The user has moved to a residential area that requires parking permits and needs to know how to get one.
response: Welcome to your new neighborhood! To obtain a residential parking permit, you'll need: 1) Proof of residency (utility bill or lease dated within 60 days), 2) Your vehicle registration showing the vehicle is registered to your address, and 3) A valid ID. You can apply online at [city].gov/parking-permits or in person at the Transportation Department office. The annual fee is typically $25-50 depending on your zone. Once approved, you'll receive your permit within 5-7 business days by mail, or immediately if applying in person.

instruction: Provide information about noise complaints
context: The user is experiencing consistent noise from a neighboring property and wants to know what can be done.
response: I'm sorry you're experiencing this disturbance. For noise complaints, we recommend: 1) First try speaking with your neighbor about the issue, 2) If that doesn't resolve it, you can file a noise complaint by calling 311 or through our website/app. Please note the time, duration, and type of noise. Noise ordinances typically restrict loud sounds between 10 PM and 7 AM on weekdays, and 11 PM to 8 AM on weekends. An officer may be dispatched to assess the noise level. Multiple documented complaints may result in citations for the property owner.

instruction: Answer question about water bill payment options
context: The user received a higher than normal water bill and wants to know about payment plans.
response: I understand receiving an unexpectedly high water bill can be concerning. The city offers several options: 1) Payment plans that allow you to spread the balance over 3-6 months without penalties, 2) One-time payment extensions of up to 30 days, 3) Financial assistance programs for eligible residents. You can also request a meter check if you suspect a reading error. To arrange any of these options, please contact our Water Department directly at (555) 123-4567 or visit [city].gov/water-billing. They can also help determine if you might have a leak or other issue causing the high usage.

instruction: Provide information about building permits
context: The user wants to build a deck on their property and needs to know about permit requirements.
response: For building a deck, you will likely need a building permit. Here's what you should know: 1) Permits are required for decks that are more than 30 inches above grade or attached to the house, 2) You'll need to submit plans showing dimensions, materials, and structural details, 3) The application fee is typically $150-300 depending on the project size, 4) Processing usually takes 10-15 business days. You can apply online through our Building Department portal or in person. I'd recommend consulting with a building inspector at (555) 234-5678 before starting your project to understand all requirements and avoid potential issues.

instruction: Answer question about street cleaning schedule
context: The user wants to know when street cleaning happens in their neighborhood to avoid parking tickets.
response: Street cleaning schedules vary by neighborhood. To find your specific schedule: 1) Check the street signs on your block which display the regular cleaning days and hours, 2) Visit our website at [city].gov/street-cleaning and enter your address, 3) Use our city mobile app which can send you reminders, or 4) Call 311 with your address for immediate information. Generally, street cleaning occurs twice monthly between April and November. Remember that vehicles parked during posted street cleaning hours may receive a $45 ticket and possible towing. You can sign up for text or email alerts to remind you before your scheduled cleaning days.

instruction: Provide information about recycling guidelines
context: The user is confused about what items can be recycled in the city's program.
response: Our city accepts the following recyclable items: 1) Paper products (newspapers, magazines, cardboard), 2) Plastic containers with recycling symbols 1-5, 3) Metal cans (aluminum, steel, tin), 4) Glass bottles and jars. Please rinse containers before recycling and remove caps from bottles. Items that cannot be recycled include: plastic bags, styrofoam, electronics, food waste, and greasy pizza boxes. For electronics, hazardous waste, or large items, please use our special collection services. You can download our recycling guide with photos at [city].gov/recycling or request a printed copy by calling 311.

instruction: Explain process for reporting abandoned vehicles
context: The user notices a car that hasn't moved for several weeks and appears abandoned.
response: To report a potentially abandoned vehicle, please provide: 1) The exact location (address or intersection), 2) Vehicle description (make, model, color), 3) License plate number if visible, 4) How long it appears to have been stationary, and 5) Any notable conditions (damaged, missing parts, flat tires, etc.). You can report this through our mobile app, website, or by calling 311. Vehicles are considered abandoned if they haven't moved for 72+ hours and show signs of neglect. Our parking enforcement will tag the vehicle for removal, giving the owner 72 hours to move it before it may be towed. There's no fee for reporting.

instruction: Provide information about dog licenses
context: The user recently adopted a dog and needs to know about licensing requirements.
response: Congratulations on your new furry family member! All dogs over 4 months old must be licensed in our city. To obtain a license, you'll need: 1) Proof of current rabies vaccination, 2) Proof of spaying/neutering (for discounted fee), 3) Your contact information and description of the dog. Licenses cost $20 annually for spayed/neutered dogs and $60 for unaltered dogs. You can apply online at [city].gov/pet-licensing, through our mobile app, by mail, or in person at Animal Services. Licenses must be renewed annually. Your dog should wear the license tag at all times when outside. Failure to license your dog may result in a $150 fine.

instruction: Answer question about property tax assessment
context: The user believes their property tax assessment is too high and wants to know how to contest it.
response: If you believe your property assessment is incorrect, you can appeal through these steps: 1) Review your assessment notice for errors in square footage, property features, etc., 2) Research comparable properties in your neighborhood to support your case, 3) File an appeal with the Assessment Review Board within 60 days of receiving your assessment notice. You can file online at [city].gov/tax-appeals or in person at the Tax Assessor's Office. Supporting documentation should include recent appraisals, evidence of structural issues, or sales data for similar properties. There's a $25 filing fee, which is refunded if your appeal is successful. The review process typically takes 30-45 days.

instruction: Provide information about tree removal on public property
context: The user is concerned about a potentially dangerous tree on the sidewalk in front of their home.
response: Thank you for your concern about public safety. For trees on public property (sidewalks, medians, parks): 1) Report the concerning tree through our mobile app, website, or by calling 311, 2) Provide the exact location and photos if possible, 3) Describe why you believe the tree poses a hazard (dead branches, leaning, disease, etc.). Our Urban Forestry division will inspect the tree within 3-5 business days. If deemed hazardous, removal will be scheduled based on risk priority. Please note that healthy trees are rarely removed, but pruning or other maintenance may be performed instead. There is no cost to residents for the maintenance of trees on public property.

instruction: Answer question about obtaining birth certificates
context: The user needs to get copies of birth certificates for their family.
response: To obtain birth certificates in our city: 1) Visit the Vital Records Office in person at City Hall (fastest method), 2) Apply online at [city].gov/vital-records, or 3) Submit a request by mail. You'll need to provide identification (government-issued photo ID) and pay a fee of $25 for the first copy and $15 for each additional copy ordered at the same time. If you're requesting someone else's birth certificate, you must be an immediate family member, legal representative, or guardian. Processing takes 1-2 business days for in-person requests, 5-7 days for online requests, and 2-3 weeks for mail requests.

instruction: Provide information about reporting power outages
context: The user is experiencing a power outage and wants to know who to contact.
response: For power outages, you should contact the utility company directly, not 311. Our local electric provider is [Utility Name] and can be reached at (555) 888-9999 or through their outage reporting app. Before calling, check if your neighbors also lost power to help determine if it's a widespread issue. Have your account number or service address ready. The utility company maintains a real-time outage map at [utility].com/outages with estimated restoration times. If you see downed power lines, stay at least 30 feet away and call 911 immediately, as this is considered an emergency situation.

instruction: Answer question about animal control services
context: The user spotted a stray dog in their neighborhood and wants to know what to do.
response: If you've found a stray dog, you have several options: 1) If the animal appears friendly and approachable, check for ID tags, 2) Call Animal Control at (555) 456-7890 for immediate assistance, especially if the animal seems injured or aggressive, 3) Report through our mobile app with a photo and location, 4) Take the animal to the nearest shelter if you can safely transport it. Our Animal Services officers typically respond within 1-4 hours depending on priority. Do not attempt to approach animals that appear aggressive or injured. If you're able to temporarily keep the animal safe, Animal Services can bring a microchip scanner to check for owner information.

instruction: Provide information about public transportation options
context: The user is new to the city and wants to learn about available public transit.
response: Welcome to our city! We offer several public transportation options: 1) Bus system with 45 routes covering most neighborhoods, running from 5:30 AM to midnight (reduced service on weekends), 2) Light rail with 3 lines connecting downtown to major suburbs, running from 4:30 AM to 1:30 AM, 3) Bike share program with 200+ stations throughout the city. Fares are $2.50 for a single ride, $5 for a day pass, or $75 for a monthly pass that works across all services. Discounts are available for seniors, students, and low-income residents. Download our transit app for real-time arrivals and trip planning, or visit [city].gov/transit for maps and schedules.

instruction: Answer question about reporting graffiti
context: The user wants to report graffiti on a public building.
response: Thank you for helping keep our city clean! To report graffiti: 1) Use our mobile app to submit a photo and location (preferred method), 2) Report online at [city].gov/graffiti, or 3) Call 311. For graffiti on public property (parks, government buildings, schools), our city's Graffiti Removal Team will address it within 48-72 hours at no cost. For private property, we offer free removal supplies to property owners or one free professional removal per year. If the graffiti contains offensive language or hate speech, please note this in your report as it will be prioritized for same-day removal. There is no penalty for reporting, and you can remain anonymous if preferred.

instruction: Provide information about library card registration
context: The user wants to get a library card for themselves and their children.
response: Getting a library card is easy and free! Here's what you need to know: 1) Adults (18+) need to bring a photo ID and proof of current address (utility bill, lease, etc.), 2) Children under 18 need a parent/guardian present with their ID, 3) You can start the application online at [city].gov/library but will need to visit any branch in person to verify ID and pick up your card. Library cards provide access to physical materials, e-books, audiobooks, online courses, museum passes, and computer/wifi use. There are no annual fees, though there are charges for late returns or damaged items. Cards must be renewed every 3 years. Each family member, including children, can have their own card with age-appropriate access levels.

instruction: Answer question about bulk trash collection
context: The user is moving and has large furniture items to dispose of.
response: For bulk trash disposal, you have several options: 1) Schedule a special collection through our website or by calling 311. This service is available once per quarter at no charge, with additional pickups available for $25 each, 2) Drop items off at our Transfer Station at 123 Disposal Road (open Tuesday-Saturday, 8 AM-4 PM) for a fee based on weight, 3) Request our

service for gently used items, which donates suitable pieces to local charities. Please schedule bulk pickups at least one week in advance. Items should be placed at the curb no earlier than 24 hours before your scheduled pickup. Acceptable items include furniture, appliances, and large household goods. Construction debris, electronics, and hazardous waste require special handling.

instruction: Provide information about city parks and recreation facilities
context: The user wants to find parks with specific amenities like basketball courts and picnic areas.
response: Our city has 45 parks with various amenities. To find parks with specific features: 1) Use our interactive park finder at [city].gov/parks where you can filter by amenities, 2) Check our mobile app's

section which includes photos and real-time availability for reservable spaces, 3) Call our Parks & Recreation office at (555) 765-4321 for personalized recommendations. Most parks are open from sunrise to sunset. Features like basketball courts are available on a first-come basis, while picnic pavilions can be reserved for $25-75 depending on size. For basketball courts specifically, Franklin Park, Riverside Park, and Jefferson Park all have well-maintained courts with lights that stay on until 10 PM. Would you like information about any specific park?

instruction: Answer question about voter registration
context: The user recently moved and needs to update their voter registration.
response: After moving, you should update your voter registration within 30 days. You can: 1) Register online at [state].gov/vote if you have a state ID or driver's license, 2) Complete a paper form available at any public library, post office, or DMV, 3) Visit the County Clerk's office in person at 456 Government Plaza. You'll need to provide your new address, previous registration address, and the last four digits of your SSN. The deadline to register for upcoming elections is typically 30 days before election day. Once registered, you'll receive a voter card in the mail within 2-3 weeks confirming your polling location. If you register close to an election, you may need to bring ID to the polls your first time voting at the new location.

instruction: Provide information about small business permits
context: The user wants to open a small cafe and needs information about required permits.
response: Congratulations on your new business venture! For opening a cafe, you'll typically need: 1) Business License ($150-300 annually), 2) Food Service Permit ($200-500 based on seating capacity), 3) Health Department Inspection (scheduled after applying for food permit), 4) Certificate of Occupancy (if changing the building's use), 5) Signage Permit if installing outdoor signs, and 6) Alcohol License if serving alcohol (separate state application required). Our Small Business Resource Center at City Hall offers free consultations to walk you through the process. I recommend starting with them, as they can provide a customized checklist and timeline. The entire permitting process typically takes 6-8 weeks. You can begin the application process online at [city].gov/business-permits.

instruction: Answer question about after-school programs
context: The user is looking for affordable after-school activities for their elementary school children.
response: Our city offers several affordable after-school options for elementary students: 1) The Parks & Recreation Department runs programs at 12 community centers from 3-6 PM on school days for $75-150/month (sliding scale based on income), 2) The Library's

program is free at all branches from 3:30-5:30 PM, 3) The School District offers on-site after-care at most elementary schools for $100-200/month. Income-based scholarships are available for all these programs. Registration for fall programs typically opens in July, with limited spots available. Most programs offer activities such as homework help, sports, arts, and STEM activities. For specific program details and availability, visit [city].gov/after-school or call our Youth Services office at (555) 234-5678.

instruction: Provide information about reporting water main breaks
context: The user notices water gushing from the street and wants to know what to do.
response: A water main break requires immediate attention! Please: 1) Call our Water Emergency line at (555) 998-7777 right away (this line is staffed 24/7), 2) If you can't reach that number, call 311 or use our emergency reporting feature on the mobile app. Please provide the exact location and describe the severity (amount of water, whether it's affecting traffic, etc.). While waiting for response, avoid driving through flowing water as there may be hidden hazards or sinkholes forming. Crews typically respond within 30-60 minutes. If the water is entering buildings or creating dangerous traffic conditions, also call 911. Note that water service in the area may need to be shut off temporarily during repairs.

instruction: Answer question about renewing driver's license
context: The user needs to renew their driver's license and isn't sure where to go.
response: Driver's licenses are issued by the state, not the city, but I can help direct you: 1) For standard renewals, visit the DMV office at 789 Motor Avenue (open Monday-Friday 8 AM-5 PM, and Saturdays 8 AM-noon), 2) You can also renew online at [state].gov/dmv if your license is not expired and you're not due for a new photo, 3) For Real ID-compliant licenses, you must apply in person with additional documentation. Currently, the average wait time at our local DMV is approximately 45 minutes, but you can make an appointment online to reduce your wait. Renewal fees are $32 for a standard 4-year license. If your license has been expired for more than 60 days, you may need to retake the written test. For more specific information, please contact the state DMV directly at (555) 111-2222.

instruction: Provide information about community gardens
context: The user wants to participate in a community garden in their neighborhood.
response: Our city has 22 community gardens across different neighborhoods. To join one: 1) Check availability by visiting [city].gov/community-gardens or calling our Parks Department at (555) 876-5432, 2) Submit an application for the garden nearest you (plots are typically assigned in February for the growing season), 3) Pay the annual fee of $25-40 depending on plot size. Most gardens provide water access, basic tools, and compost. New gardeners may be placed on a waiting list for popular locations, but several gardens have immediate openings. If you're new to gardening, we offer free monthly workshops at the Community Center. Some gardens also have communal plots that welcome drop-in volunteers on designated work days, usually Saturday mornings, which is a great way to get involved while waiting for your own plot.

instruction: Answer question about street light outages
context: The user wants to report a broken street light in their neighborhood.
response: To report a street light outage: 1) Note the pole number (usually a metal tag on the pole) or nearest address, 2) Report through our mobile app (fastest method) where you can upload a photo, 3) Submit online at [city].gov/street-lights, or 4) Call 311. Repairs are typically completed within 3-5 business days, though it may take longer if there are underground electrical issues or if replacement parts need to be ordered. If multiple consecutive lights are out or if the outage is in a high-crime area, repairs will be prioritized. For flickering lights or damaged poles that pose a safety hazard, please mention this in your report. There is no fee for reporting or repairs as street light maintenance is covered by city taxes.

instruction: Provide information about snow removal guidelines
context: The user wants to know their responsibilities for clearing snow from sidewalks.
response: Property owners are responsible for clearing snow from sidewalks adjacent to their property within 24 hours after snowfall ends. Here are the guidelines: 1) Clear a path at least 3 feet wide along the full length of your sidewalk, 2) Clear access to fire hydrants and storm drains if they're adjacent to your property, 3) Do not shovel snow into the street, bike lanes, or onto others' property. For elderly or disabled residents, our

program provides volunteer shoveling assistance—call (555) 789-0123 to request help or volunteer. Failure to clear sidewalks may result in a warning for first offenses, followed by fines starting at $50 for subsequent violations. The city is responsible for plowing streets, with main arteries cleared first, followed by secondary streets and residential areas.

instruction: Answer question about obtaining marriage licenses
context: The user is planning to get married and needs information about getting a license.
response: Congratulations on your upcoming marriage! To obtain a marriage license: 1) Both partners must appear together at the County Clerk's Office (123 Government Way, Room 210), 2) Bring government-issued photo ID and proof of age for both parties, 3) Complete the application form (available online to pre-fill before your visit), 4) Pay the $75 fee (credit card, cash, or money order). No blood tests are required in our state. The license is valid for 90 days from issuance, and there is a 3-day waiting period before it can be used. The office is open Monday-Friday, 8:30 AM-4:30 PM, with extended hours until 7 PM on Wednesdays. No appointment is needed, but wait times are shortest early in the day. For more information, you can call the County Clerk's Office directly at (555) 321-7890.

instruction: Provide information about reporting code violations
context: The user is concerned about unsafe conditions at a neighboring property.
response: For property code violations, you can: 1) Report online at [city].gov/code-enforcement with photos if possible, 2) Use our mobile app's

feature, 3) Call our Code Enforcement division at (555) 543-2109, or 4) Email codeenforcement@[city].gov. Common violations include unsafe structures, excessive garbage, abandoned vehicles, overgrown vegetation (over 12 inches), and illegal construction without permits. Your report can remain anonymous if preferred. After receiving a report, an inspector will visit the property within 1-5 business days depending on the severity. Property owners typically receive a notice giving them 10-30 days to correct issues before fines begin at $100-500 per day depending on the violation. For immediately dangerous conditions, inspectors can take emergency action.

instruction: Answer question about paying parking tickets
context: The user received a parking ticket and wants to know how to pay or contest it.
response: For parking tickets, you have several options: 1) Pay online at [city].gov/parking-tickets (fastest method), 2) Pay by phone at (555) 888-7766, 3) Pay in person at the Parking Authority (400 Traffic Way), or 4) Mail a check to the address on the ticket. Payments are due within 21 days of issuance. After that, a $25 late fee is added. To contest a ticket, you must file an appeal within 14 days either online or using the form on the back of the ticket. Appeals are reviewed within 30 days, during which the due date is suspended. If you have evidence supporting your appeal (photos, receipts, etc.), be sure to include it. Payment plans are available for those with multiple tickets or financial hardship—contact the Parking Authority directly at (555) 888-7766 to discuss options.

instruction: Provide information about senior citizen programs
context: The user's elderly parent has moved to the city and they want to know about available services.
response: Welcome to your parent! Our Senior Services include: 1) Senior Centers at 5 locations offering free activities, classes, and meals (open Monday-Friday, 9 AM-4 PM), 2) Dial-A-Ride transportation for medical appointments and essential errands ($2 per ride, must schedule 48 hours in advance), 3) Meals on Wheels delivery for homebound seniors, 4) Senior Tax Assistance program during tax season, 5) Recreation programs with age-specific fitness classes at discounted rates, and 6) Senior Safety program offering free home safety evaluations and basic modifications. Most services are available to residents 60+ at no or low cost. To access these services, register with our Office on Aging at (555) 654-3210 or visit [city].gov/senior-services. They can conduct a needs assessment and connect your parent with appropriate resources, including non-city programs like utility discounts and prescription assistance.

instruction: Answer question about COVID-19 testing sites
context: The user is feeling unwell and wants to know where to get tested for COVID-19.
response: For COVID-19 testing, we have several options: 1) City Health Department drive-through site at 123 Medical Parkway (open daily 8 AM-6 PM, appointments recommended but walk-ins accepted), 2) Community Health Center at 456 Wellness Avenue (open Monday-Friday 9 AM-5 PM, appointment required), 3) Mobile testing units that visit different neighborhoods weekly (schedule at [city].gov/covid-testing), 4) Most pharmacies and urgent care facilities also offer testing. PCR and rapid tests are available at all city-run sites. Results typically come within 24-48 hours for PCR tests and 15-30 minutes for rapid tests. Most locations accept insurance, and free testing is available for uninsured residents. For home test kits, our libraries distribute free kits (limit 2 per person) during regular hours while supplies last. If you're experiencing severe symptoms, please contact your healthcare provider or visit an emergency room.

instruction: Provide information about utility assistance programs
context: The user is having trouble paying their utility bills and needs help.
response: I'm sorry to hear you're having difficulty with your bills. Our city offers several assistance programs: 1) Utility Relief Program providing up to $500 annually for income-eligible households (applications at [city].gov/utility-help), 2) Budget Billing Plan that averages your bills throughout the year to avoid seasonal spikes, 3) Payment extensions of up to 60 days available by calling the Utility Billing office at (555) 222-3333, 4) Weatherization assistance to help reduce energy costs long-term. Additionally, the Community Action Agency (not city-run) offers emergency utility assistance—contact them at (555) 444-5555. To qualify for most programs, your household income must be below 200% of the federal poverty level. Documentation required typically includes proof of income, residency, and copies of recent utility bills. The application process takes about 2-3 weeks, but emergency assistance may be available for shut-off notices.

instruction: Answer question about scheduling building inspections
context: The user is renovating their home and needs to schedule required inspections.
response: To schedule a building inspection: 1) Use our online portal at [city].gov/building-inspections (available 24/7), 2) Call our automated scheduling line at (555) 123-4567 (available 24/7), or 3) Call the Building Department directly at (555) 765-4321 during business hours (Monday-Friday, 8 AM-5 PM). Please schedule at least 24 hours in advance. Have your permit number ready when scheduling. Inspections are conducted Monday-Friday between 8:30 AM and 4 PM. You can request AM or PM appointments, but specific times cannot be guaranteed. Someone over 18 must be present for interior inspections. Failed inspections require correction and re-inspection, which can be scheduled after corrections are made. There is no additional fee for the first re-inspection, but subsequent re-inspections incur a $75 fee. For questions about specific code requirements, ask to speak with the inspector assigned to your area.

instruction: Provide information about swimming pool safety requirements
context: The user is installing a backyard pool and wants to know about safety regulations.
response: For residential pools, our city code requires: 1) A fence or barrier at least 4 feet high surrounding the pool area with no gaps larger than 4 inches, 2) Self-closing and self-latching gates that open outward, with latches at least 54 inches above the ground, 3) Alarms on all doors and windows with direct access to the pool area, 4) Pool covers must be motorized or require a key/combination to remove, 5) At least one life-saving device (ring buoy or reaching pole) near the pool. Before filling your pool, you'll need a safety inspection—schedule through our Building Department at (555) 987-6543. The inspection fee is $75. Above-ground pools with walls at least 4 feet high may be exempt from some fencing requirements if ladder access is secured. Non-compliance can result in fines starting at $250 per day. For detailed specifications, pick up our pool safety guide at City Hall or download it at [city].gov/pool-safety.

instruction: Answer question about public records requests
context: The user wants to access records about a recent city construction project.
response: To request public records: 1) Submit a request through our online portal at [city].gov/records-request (preferred method), 2) Complete a paper form available at City Hall, or 3) Email recordsrequest@[city].gov with your specific request. Be as detailed as possible about the records you're seeking, including date ranges and relevant departments. Standard requests are processed within 5-10 business days. Expedited requests may be available for an additional fee. Fees are $0.15 per page for physical copies, $25/hour for staff research time exceeding 30 minutes, and electronic records may be provided at no cost. Fee waivers are available if the request is in the public interest. Construction project records typically include permits, inspection reports, and approved plans, though some proprietary or security-sensitive information may be redacted. You can check the status of your request online using the confirmation number provided when you submit.

instruction: Provide information about mosquito control services
context: The user is concerned about mosquitos in their neighborhood and possible disease risks.
response: Our city takes mosquito control seriously. Here's what we offer: 1) Weekly larvicide treatment of public areas with standing water from April through October, 2) Mosquito surveillance and testing for diseases like West Nile virus, 3) Targeted spraying in areas with confirmed mosquito-borne illness (announced 48 hours in advance on our website and via neighborhood alerts), 4) Free property inspections to identify breeding sites—request through our Health Department at (555) 777-8888. To reduce mosquitos around your home: eliminate standing water in gutters, planters, and containers; keep grass trimmed; use EPA-approved repellents; and report abandoned properties with stagnant pools or chronic water issues. You can also request free mosquito dunks (larvicide tablets for water features) at any fire station during business hours. For persistent problems in your area, submit a service request via 311 with the specific location details.

instruction: Answer question about holiday trash collection schedule
context: The user wants to know if trash will be collected on an upcoming holiday.
response: Our Sanitation Department observes the following holidays with no collection services: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Day. When your regular collection day falls on one of these holidays, service is delayed by one day for the remainder of that week. For example, if the holiday falls on a Tuesday, Tuesday's routes will be collected Wednesday, Wednesday's on Thursday, and so on through Saturday. There is no service delay if the holiday falls on a weekend. You can view the full holiday schedule for the year at [city].gov/holiday-collection or sign up for collection day reminders via text or email. The holiday schedule is also published in the quarterly city newsletter mailed to all residents. For specific questions about your route, call Sanitation directly at (555) 123-4567.
